A. On August 13, 2019, there was a work accident at E.________ AG in U.________, where A.________ was injured in his right hand. He filed a criminal complaint against B.B.________ and unknown perpetrators for serious, alternatively simple or negligent bodily harm on October 7, 2019.

B. The Youth Prosecutors Office of the Canton of Solothurn did not pursue the criminal complaint in a decision dated October 6, 2020. The appeal filed by A.________ against the decision was dismissed by the Solothurn Cantonal Court on December 17, 2020.

C. A.________ has appealed to the Federal Court, requesting the annulment of the Cantonal Courts decision and instructing the Youth Prosecutors Office to pursue the criminal complaint. The Cantonal Court and the Youth Prosecutors Office have both waived their right to respond, referring to the contested decision or the decision not to pursue the complaint. B.B.________ did not submit a response within the deadline.

Case Summary: 

On August 13, 2019, A.________ sustained an injury to his right hand in a work-related accident at E.________ AG in U.________. Subsequently, A.________ filed a criminal complaint on October 7, 2019, against B.B.________ and unknown individuals, alleging serious, alternatively simple, or negligent bodily harm. The Youth Prosecutor's Office of the Canton of Solothurn decided not to pursue the complaint on October 6, 2020. A.________ appealed this decision, but the Solothurn Cantonal Court dismissed the appeal on December 17, 2020. A.________ has now appealed to the Federal Court, seeking the annulment of the Cantonal Court's decision and requesting that the Youth Prosecutor's Office be instructed to pursue the criminal complaint. Both the Cantonal Court and the Youth Prosecutor's Office have waived their right to respond, while B.B.________ did not submit a response within the given deadline.

Please say “exit” if the summary is good or provide any additional information or corrections to edit the summary. Examples of key information that could be added include details about the nature of the injury, any previous legal actions taken by A.________, or specific reasons for the Youth Prosecutor's Office's decision not to pursue the complaint.

I have been trying for years to establish contact with my children through the KESB Appenzell Ausserrhoden. I filed a complaint with the Appenzell Ausserrhoden Higher Court on May 8, 2017, regarding delays in the legal process. The Higher Court informed me on July 5, 2017, that the case has been transferred to the Cantonal Court and merged with an ongoing maintenance case. They stated that the complaint against the KESB is now irrelevant and that there has been no delay in the proceedings at the Cantonal Court. As a result, they will soon close the complaint. In response, I filed a complaint with the Federal Court on August 23, 2017, requesting a declaration of delay and a decision within 30 days.

Case Summary: The client has been attempting to establish contact with their children through the KESB Appenzell Ausserrhoden for several years. On May 8, 2017, the client filed a complaint with the Appenzell Ausserrhoden Higher Court regarding delays in the legal process. On July 5, 2017, the Higher Court informed the client that the case had been transferred to the Cantonal Court and merged with an ongoing maintenance case, rendering the complaint against the KESB irrelevant and stating that there had been no delay in the proceedings at the Cantonal Court. In short, he considered, regarding the intervention of B.________, that the investigation had established that the complainant had not accepted being denied entry to the club on the grounds that he did not have identification and had refused to leave the premises. As for the two colleagues of the security guard, there was no evidence in the file to suggest that the second security guard at the club on the night of the incident had physically attacked the complainant. The surveillance camera footage clearly showed that this guard was inside the nightclub at the time the suspect and the complainant ended up on the ground, which is why E.________ intervened. As for the latter, the Prosecutor noted that the surveillance camera footage showed that he had merely grabbed the complainants legs and then held him down and handcuffed him. Handcuffing the complainant while waiting for the police to arrive did not appear disproportionate given his behavior. Furthermore, the complainant had provided no evidence of injuries caused by improper handcuffing. Thirdly, no evidence corroborated the complainants claims that B.________ had made threats. On the contrary, it seemed more likely that it was the complainant who had behaved inappropriately. In the presence of irreconcilably contradictory versions, the suspect had to be given the benefit of the doubt. **Case Summary:**

On March 27, 2018, A.________ filed a criminal complaint against a security guard (B.________) at the nightclub "C.________" in U.________, and against the police officers who intervened later. A.________ alleged that B.________ threatened and physically assaulted him after refusing him entry to the nightclub. He claimed that B.________, with the help of two colleagues, undressed him, hit him, and restrained him with overly tight handcuffs. A.________ also accused the police officers of leaving him shirtless in the cold and with tight handcuffs, causing severe pain, and of refusing to register his complaint against B.________.

After an investigation, including witness interviews and reviewing surveillance footage, the public prosecutor decided to dismiss the complaint on June 18, 2020. The prosecutor found that A.________ had been insistent on entering the club without identification and had not complied with the security guards' orders to leave. The intervention by B.________ was deemed appropriate and proportionate. Surveillance footage and witness statements corroborated B.________'s account, showing no evidence of physical assault by the security guards. The prosecutor also found no evidence of injuries caused by improper handcuffing or threats made by B.________. The benefit of the doubt was given to the suspect due to irreconcilable contradictory versions of the events.

A.
In 2006 and 2007, Y (defendant) had various construction and renovation work done on a property. He entered into contracts with X (plaintiff) as the contractor and project manager. 

B.
The parties disputed the amount of payment, the scope of the project management, and whether the project management was done negligently. The plaintiff filed a lawsuit on June 26, 2009, seeking payment of approximately CHF 62,510.16 (or EUR 37,885.20) plus interest. The defendant denied the claim and counterclaimed for the return of overpaid fees and damages, at least CHF 147,000 plus interest. The District Court of Kriens ruled on July 18, 2012, that the defendant must pay the plaintiff CHF 62,510.60 plus interest and dismissed the counterclaim. On the defendants appeal, the Higher Court of the Canton of Lucerne awarded the plaintiff only CHF 9,042 and dismissed the counterclaim. It ordered the plaintiff to pay 16% of the first-instance costs and one-fourth of the second-instance costs.

C.
The plaintiff filed an appeal with the Federal Court on April 30, 2013, seeking to overturn the Higher Courts decision and to have the defendant ordered to pay CHF 58,405.90 plus interest. The plaintiff also challenged the allocation of costs in the first-instance proceedings, arguing that a pre-litigation settlement proposal should have been considered under cantonal law. Regarding the interest, the plaintiff argued that the Higher Court did not award any interest on the amount granted, even though the first-instance decision did not raise any objections in this regard. On May 27, 2013, the Higher Court corrected its decision in accordance with the reasoning contained therein and awarded the plaintiff interest on the amount of CHF 9,042 from January 8, 2008. The defendant requests that the appeal be dismissed with costs. In the event that the appeal is found to be justified, he criticizes various aspects of the contested decision that were unfavorable to him. He also argues in the response to the appeal that he should have been obligated to pay EUR 5,480 instead of CHF 9,042. The Higher Court refers to the correction decision and rejects the imposition of costs, as a short letter would have sufficed to remedy this defect. To the extent that the appeal has not become moot due to the correction, the Higher Court requests that it be dismissed with costs.

Case Summary:
In 2006 and 2007, Y (defendant) engaged X (plaintiff) for construction and renovation work, including project management. Disputes arose regarding payment, project scope, and alleged negligence in project management. On June 26, 2009, the plaintiff sued for CHF 62,510.16 plus interest. The defendant counterclaimed for overpaid fees and damages totaling at least CHF 147,000 plus interest. The District Court of Kriens ruled in favor of the plaintiff for CHF 62,510.60 plus interest and dismissed the counterclaim. On appeal, the Higher Court of the Canton of Lucerne reduced the award to CHF 9,042 and dismissed the counterclaim, adjusting the cost allocation accordingly.

The plaintiff appealed to the Federal Court on April 30, 2013, seeking CHF 58,405.90 plus interest and challenging the cost allocation. The Higher Court corrected its decision on May 27, 2013, awarding interest on CHF 9,042 from January 8, 2008. The defendant requested dismissal of the appeal and, if justified, raised objections to unfavorable aspects of the decision, arguing for a payment of EUR 5,480 instead of CHF 9,042. The Higher Court maintained its correction and requested dismissal of the appeal with costs.

Please say “exit” if the summary is good or provide any additional information or corrections to edit the summary. Examples of key information that could be added include specific details about the alleged negligence, the nature of the overpaid fees, or any pre-litigation settlement proposals.
